Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Revascularization vs. Non-Operative Management in Intermittent Claudication

Trial_Design.evidence: Eligible IC patients were randomised to either revascularization (bypass or PVI) or non-operative management (medication and exercise therapy).

Participants.evidence: Eligible IC patients were randomised to either revascularization (bypass or PVI) or non-operative management (medication and exercise therapy).

Intervention.evidence: Eligible IC patients were randomised to either revascularization (bypass or PVI) or non-operative management (medication and exercise therapy).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was patient-reported physical function (PROMIS-PF) and satisfaction in social roles (PROMIS-SA) over a follow-up of up to 7 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 225 patients were randomised: 89 to revascularization and 136 to non-operative management.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted using a linear mixed-effect model adjusted for covariates.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were found in PROMIS-PF between groups over time (P=0.07). PROMIS-SA improved significantly in all patients (P=0.019), with greater improvement in the non-operative group (P=0.045).
